stem: A rock climber notices reduced grip strength when using a power grip (metacarpophalangeal flexion with interphalangeal extension). Examination shows weakness of interossei and lumbricals to digits 4 and 5, while wrist flexion with ulnar deviation is preserved. Which nerve branch is responsible for the weak power grip?

choices.A: Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
choices.C: Recurrent branch of the median nerve
choices.E: Superficial branch of the ulnar nerve

rationale_correct: Power grip depends on the intrinsic hand muscles (interossei, lumbricals) supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve; weakness indicates its dysfunction.

rationale_distractors.B: The anterior interosseous nerve controls deep flexors of digits 1â€“3, not interossei.
rationale_distractors.C: The recurrent median branch innervates thenar muscles for thumb opposition.
rationale_distractors.D: Posterior interosseous nerve controls finger extensors, not intrinsic flexion.
rationale_distractors.E: The superficial ulnar branch is sensory, not motor.
